The only reason people put down Hoover is to glorify Roosevelt, the fascist.

 Roosevelt, the savior of capitalism:
 
The country was entitled to something more bracing than Herbert Hoover's defeatist, self-exculpatory gloom. Economics was then not as exact a science as it has become; Roosevelt was no economist and in policy terms he had a severely divided entourage. He produced a smorgasbord of measures and kept those that worked. He made fairly steady progress through the 1930s, co-opting the Progressive isolationists to Keynesian economics in the early years, and then ditching them in favor of pro-defense, pro-British Southern senators and congressmen when the time came to switch from pump-priming to rearmament, and saving the world from Hitler. In this intricate process, Roosevelt never singled out specific scapegoats, and preserved the moral integrity of the nation so he could focus national attention on America's real enemies, Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan.
 
 Roosevelt spared the country the extremes of left and right that plagued every other Great Power in the 1930s. He left the U.S. twice as wealthy as it was when he assumed the presidency. As economics, the New Deal deserves a passing grade, but as crisis management it was a huge success. And in the 1930s, Roosevelt was almost the only leader of an important country who was not either a barbarous dictator, an appeaser of barbarous dictators, or an ineffectual ditherer. For these reasons, as well as his genius as a war leader, he is rightly judged the greatest American president since Lincoln.

Uh...Bush...the worst? Not even close. Perhaps the worst during my life, but in US history...not a chance.
 
 John Tyler: Elected VP under W.H. Harrison, moved back to his home in Virginia several days later. Came back to Washington only after Harrison died 30 days later. Tyler's entire cabinet except 1 resigned after his 2nd veto of the national banking act. Tyler abandoned the Whig party that Harrison was elected under vetoing their entire agenda, and was expelled by the Whig's in congress. He was a lifelong slave owner, and immediately following the outbreak of the civil war sided with the confederacy. He is the only president who was not officially mourned by the US due to his support of the confederacy. His final words were "I am going now, perhaps it is for the best." Perhaps he was right.
 
 Franklin Pierce: Supported and is generally considered ultimately responsible for the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854 which repealed the Missouri Compromise of 1820. This allowed for popular sovereignty, which allowed settlers to decide the issue of slavery in newly created territories. This did more to hasten the start of the civil war than any other action undetaken by any president. Pierce was a lifelong alcoholic who ran over an elderly woman while driving his carriage intoxicated. He was the only sitting president to not receive his party's nomination for a second term. Once attacked with a hard-boiled egg (at least it wasn't a shoe).
 
 James Buchanan: Did little to nothing to stem the tide of secession, allowing the start of the Civil War without so much as a whimper. He helped to draft the Ostend Manifesto, which proposed the purchase of Cuba from Spain in order to extend slavery. 
 
 Warren Harding: Considered to be America's most indecisive president. Once commented that the job of president was "beyond him". Nominated friends and political allies to high positions, setting the stage for what was known to be one of the most corrupt administrations in US history. A drunk, Harding frequently drank until the wee hours of the morning with his buddies (the corrupt group known as the "Ohio Gang")...during prohibition. He was reputed to have more zipper problems than Clinton, and once lost all the White House china on one hand of poker. Some believe that he was poisoned by his wife to save him from being implicated in the corruption surrounding his administation. 
 
 Bush was bad, but the worst...not quite.

Well, maybe WE don't know our history but I believe the rest of the country (well over 70%) and every foreign country in the world would agree with me. So, have yourself a great education of denial. But to be fair, I'm sure there are others worse but no other presiident has started an unnecessary war based on lies and has killed 100's of thousands unnecessarily as a result of that decision. In my book, that places him way down the line. Oh, I forgot in the process of all of this he destroyed our economy as well. You gotta love a leader like that.

 Presidents have done far worse in the past...if you honestly think that Bush is the worst president we have ever had you are simply stated that as a political and partisan attack.
I believe you already wrote this.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  The Worst President in History
